frame.name: Friendly_or_hostile
frame.definition:
<def-root>Two parties or individuals are on the same side or on different sides of a (typically military) conflict. The two sides may be expressed jointly as the <fen>Sides</fen>, or separately as <fen>Side_1</fen> and <fen>Side_2</fen>.
<ex>We received a tip from a <t>friendly</t> <fex name="Side_1">local</fex> about a possible attack. <fex name="Side_2">DNI</fex></ex>
<ex>Infiltration from <t>hostile</t> <fex name="Side_1">forces</fex> is a constant threat. <fex name="Side_2">DNI</fex></ex>
In many cases only <fen>Side_1</fen> is mentioned, leaving <fen>Side_2</fen> as the perspective from whom the description is being given (typically the speaker/writer).</def-root>

FE.name: Side_1
FE.definition:
<def-root><fen>Side_1</fen> is the party or individual in a relationship with <fen>Side_2</fen>. <fen>Side_1</fen> is the primary protagonist of the frame, and is denoted by noun and adjective targets.
<ex>The <t><fex name="sid1">hostiles</fex></t> had become adept at spotting men in the night desert.</ex>
<ex>So now <fex name="sid1">you</fex> <m>are</m> my <t>enemy</t>?</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Side_2
FE.definition:
<def-root>The party or individual with whom <fen>Side_1</fen> bears an adversarial or friendly relationship.
<ex><fex name="sid2">His</fex> <t>enemies</t> were no doubt waiting for just such a moment.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Degree
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Degree</fen> to which the relationship holds.
<ex>They mistakenly thought that the soldiers and sailors were their <fex name="deg">greatest</fex> <t>enemy</t>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Time
FE.definition:
<def-root>The time period during which the Sides have the indicated relationship with each other.
<ex><fex name="Time">Last year</fex> they were our <t>enemy</t>, but things are different now. </ex></def-root>

FE.name: Explanation
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Explanation</fen> is a proposition denoting a state of affairs from which the Sides having the relationship indicated logically follows.
<ex>Could it be that they are <t>enemies</t> <fex name="exp">because of deep-seated prejudice</fex>?</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Descriptor
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE indicates a property of <fen>Side_1</fen> or the Sides.</def-root>

FE.name: Concessive
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE signifies that the state of affairs expressed by the main clause (containing the target) occurs or holds, and something other than that state of affairs would be expected given the state of affairs in the concessive clause. </def-root>

FE.name: Place
FE.definition:
<def-root>The location where the two <fen>Sides</fen> have an adversarial relationship.
<ex>In our daily lives we are friends, but <fex name="pla">here</fex> we are bitter <t>enemies</t>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Sides
FE.definition:
<def-root>A joint expression of the two <fen>Sides</fen> with a friendly or hostile stance towards one another.
<ex>Aren't you afraid to be here? <fex name="sids">We</fex> are <t>enemies</t>!</ex></def-root>

lexUnit.name: friendly.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: belonging to the same side as an assumed individual or party.

lexUnit.name: hostile.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: belonging to an opposing side.

lexUnit.name: friendly.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a person sympathetic or aligned to another's side (especially in military conflicts).

lexUnit.name: hostile.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: an individual opposed to another side (especially in military contexts).

lexUnit.name: enemy.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: an opposing party or individual.
